body.p:
In my letter of the 14th Novr. I informed
you of steps taking here for bringing the proposed Union
under the notice of the three Congregations of this city. The
respective Trustees deemed it advisable to have separate
meetings. At the meeting held by the congregation of the
new Synagogue it was decided to send a delegate or Agent
on their part to the meeting suggested by Dr. Wise and yourself
At a meeting of the congregation of which I am a member
held on Thursday evening the 28th ultimo I submitted
certain resolutions purporting to recognise, not the utility
alone but, under existing circumstances, the absolute
necessity for such a union. The resolutions were referred
to a committee of Seven myself being one among them.

We met on Sunday the 31st ulto and though I did not
see any necessity for it as I considered we were competent
ourselves to judge whether to recommend the sending of a
delegate or not, I was over ruled and the committee decided
in writing to Dr. Rice to ascertain his sentiments upon it.

This step unnecessarily delays the presenting of the
committee's report to the congregation: what may be the
result eventually I will not venture to predict.

The discussions held at the meeting of the congregation
and at the committee convinced me that the object of the meeting
proposed by Dr. Wise and yourself was but imperfectly
understood. I endeavoured but fear with little success to
explain that it was merely to assemble together Laymen
and minsters 1d To consider the actual state of the
Jewish community in this country, and 2d. To suggest mea
sures for remedying what might be unsatisfactory in
State, and otherwise to promote the spiritual and Temporal

well being of the whole body. Some expressed fears
that the union once formed would if under the guidance
of faithless shepherds work much mischief. You
are aware in what light innovations are held by many
and the passage in
Dr. Wise's address “if we do not
stimulate all the congregations to establish good schools
and to institute a reform in their synagogues on
modern Jewish principles &c &c” was much ani
=madverted upon, and I cannot help wishing the revd
gentleman had not put it forth, though I am persuaded he
meant not that any thing should be attempted contrary
to received Laws and customs; but the word “Reform” has
acquired somehow or another a portentous meaning to
ears that revere, and properly revere our ancient institu
=tions. In short so many and conflicting were the sentiments
and opinions expressed at the meeting of the congregation
and at that of the committee, as decided me on acceding
to Mr. Alexander Kursheedt's, and other friends' with, as
well as on responding to your general invitation to give
through the occident some of my ideas upon the subject
I send you “Letters. on the formation of a Union of
the congregations of Israelites in the United States” and
will as quickly as possible follow it up with others so
that by the time the meeting takes place the public will
be in possession of my views “which will be taken only
for as much as they may be worth” If you deem it
necessary I will thank you to announce in the occident
that I perfectly coincide in the propriety of holding a meeting
and will attend it if possible. Might it not be as well
to make the period a little later, say Rosh Hodesh
Sivan, corresponding to the 22nd May, as by that time
travelling especially from the west may be expected to
be attended with less fatigue, inconvenience and perhaps
less danger: New York I think should be the place

You will no doubt receive many communications on the
subject of the Union & meeting, will you allow me to
suggest the adding of some pages to the usual number
of the occident in order that an opportunity may be afforded
to lay before the public as many of there communications
as might be deemed useful to the object, previously to
the meetings taking place

My “Letter 1st” will not, I think, occupy more
than Eight pages of the occident and I shall be glad
if it can conveniently be inserted in the number for
February I am very respectfully
